_items.body: Hi! My name is Lily. Welcome to the Training on Effective Onboarding. Are you going to onboard new people to the team soon?
Hi! That is right. I’m excited but a bit nervous.
Totally understandable! Starting off as a manager and guiding new team members through the onboarding process can be overwhelming.
You might be asking yourself, “How do I ensure new employees integrate smoothly? How do I set them up for success without overwhelming them—or myself?”
Exactly! I want to get it right, but I’m not sure where to start.

You’re not alone. Many new managers feel the same way. And let’s be honest—poor onboarding can lead to a lot of problems, like confusion, disengagement, delayed employee performance start, or even new hires leaving early.
But here’s the good news: it doesn’t have to be that way.

This course is going to simplify everything for you. We’re here to take the stress out of onboarding. You’ll learn how to introduce new hires confidently, set realistic and meaningful goals, run check-in meetings, and even tailor the entire onboarding process to fit each employee’s unique needs.
That sounds great! So it’s not a one-size-fits-all approach?

Exactly. By the time you’re done, you’ll have practical tools and strategies to make onboarding smoother and more rewarding—not just for you but for your new hires, as well. You’ll build stronger team connections, increase productivity, and create an engaged, motivated team.

title: Intro
body: Now that you’re ready to dive in, here’s what you can expect throughout this course! We’ve structured the content into five essential modules, each designed to build your confidence and skills as you lead the onboarding process for new team members.

title: Infographic Title

_items.tooltipText: Review multimedia materials in Talent LMS and complete quizzes to test your knowledge.
Join discussions with peers in Slack to share insights and ask questions.
Apply what you’ve learned by completing assignments in Google Docs.
Get personalized video feedback from your tutor through Slack using Loom.

title: Activation Quiz

_incorrect.final:
Not quite! Only these are well-structured goals:

1. Reduce customer complaints by 15% within 3 months.

2. Automate the weekly sales report process by the end of the first quarter.

3. Increase social media engagement by 10% within 2 months.


They're specific, measurable, and time-bound, which makes it easier to track progress and evaluate success.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Not quite! These are well-structured goals:

2. Automate the weekly sales report process by the end of the first quarter.

3. Increase social media engagement by 10% within 2 months.


They're specific, measurable, and time-bound, which makes it easier to track progress and evaluate success.

_feedback.correct:
That is right! These are well-structured goals:

1. Reduce customer complaints by 15% within 3 months.

2. Automate the weekly sales report process by the end of the first quarter.

3. Increase social media engagement by 10% within 2 months.


They're specific, measurable, and time-bound, which makes it easier to track progress and evaluate success.

_items.text: Reduce customer complaints by 15% within 3 months.
Automate the weekly sales report process by the end of the first quarter.
Increase client satisfaction by any means possible.
Learn all company policies and procedures.
Increase social media engagement by 10% within 2 months.
Help the marketing team improve their strategy.

body: Which of the following is an example of a well-structured goal for a new employee?

title: Accordion Title

_items.title: S (specific)
_items.body:
Your goal should be clear and specific, answering the questions: Who, What, Where, When, and Why. This helps focus efforts and avoid any ambiguity.
Example: "Improve the onboarding process for new hires" is vague. A specific goal would be "Create a new onboarding manual for new hires."

_items.title: M (measurable)
_items.body:
A goal should have criteria that allow you to track progress and know when the goal is achieved.
Example: Instead of “Increase customer satisfaction,” a measurable goal would be “Increase customer satisfaction survey scores by 10%."

_items.title: A (achievable)
_items.body:
Your goal should be realistic and attainable, considering resources, skills, and time available. It should stretch your abilities but remain possible to accomplish.
Example: “Increase revenue by 200% in one month” may not be achievable, but “Increase revenue by 10% in one month” is more realistic.

_items.title: R (relevant)
_items.body:
Goals should align with broader business objectives or personal career aspirations. It ensures the goal has a purpose and contributes to larger plans.
Example: "Learn graphic design" may not be relevant if your role is in customer service. Instead, a relevant goal might be to “Improve customer response time by 15%."

_items.title: T (time-bound)
_items.body:
A time frame adds a sense of urgency and helps prioritize your goal. It defines when you plan to achieve the goal and keeps you accountable.
Example: Instead of saying "Improve team communication," say "Improve team communication by implementing weekly check-in meetings within 30 days."

body: The employee's goals should be clear and transparent. To define these goals, use goal-setting methodologies such as SMART, FAST, PACT, or others. In this course, we break down the SMART methodology.

_items.backText:
Development Team Goal: "Reduce the number of product errors by 25% in 3 months."

Employee’s Responsibility: Support existing products and implement changes.

Probation Period Goal for the Developer: "Reduce client-reported errors in supported products by 20% in 3 months."

Analytics Team Goal: "Automate current reports within 3 months."

Employee’s Responsibility: Build and maintain reports for the sales department.

Probation Period Goal for the Analyst: "Create one automated sales funnel with customer statuses for the sales team within 3 months."

Content Team Goal: "Increase customer acquisition through content by 15% in 3 months."

Employee’s Responsibility: Responsible for managing social media.

Probation Period Goal for the Content Team Employee: "Increase customer acquisition through Facebook and LinkedIn by 10% in 3 months."

title: Text Title
body:
Probation goals should be established before the employee is hired, with 1-3 goals in total.

  • Goals are set when the manager identifies the need for a new hire and defines the tasks they will perform.
  • Goals are used when drafting the job description, so the new hire should already be aware of them before starting.
  • Goals are further discussed in detail with the employee during their first week of work.


The goals should be carefully aligned with the reasons for hiring the new employee and the overarching objectives of the team they will join.

title: MCQ Title

_items.text: The goal should be measurable so that progress can be tracked.
The goal should be clearly defined and unambiguous.
The goal should be flexible enough to change over time.
The goal should align with team objectives.

body: Which of the following statements best describes the "Specific" component of SMART goals?

title: MCQ Title
body: Which of the following is an example of a SMART goal?

_items.text: The goal should be flexible enough to change over time.
The goal should align with team objectives.
